definition: Unmerited favor of God toward humanity, especially evident in salvation through Christ. Rooted in the idea of divine generosity, not earned merit.
Confident trust in God’s promises, character, and plan. A covenantal loyalty that underpins righteousness (Romans 4).
Violation of divine law or falling short of God's standard. Includes willful rebellion and moral failure.
God’s act of rescuing from sin and death, fulfilled through Christ. Encompasses both justification and final glorification.

Willful alignment with God’s revealed commands. In Scripture, obedience reflects covenant loyalty—seen not just in action but in heart posture. Christ’s obedience unto death is the model of ultimate discipleship (Philippians 2:8).
A sacred relational bond initiated by God with individuals or communities. Covenants define the terms of divine-human interaction—foundational in the narratives of Abraham, Moses, David, and Christ.
The progressive process by which believers are made holy. It follows justification and is fueled by the Holy Spirit, setting the Christian apart for divine purposes (1 Thessalonians 4:3).

The visible and intrinsic majesty of God. In the Old Testament, associated with overwhelming presence; in the New, revealed fully in Christ. Glory is both God’s nature and what He bestows on those united with Him.
The ability to live rightly in reverence toward God. Wisdom in Scripture is not mere intellect—it’s moral and spiritual orientation that produces righteous action (Proverbs 1:7).
What aligns with God’s character, promises, and revelation. Jesus claims to be “the Truth” (John 14:6), anchoring truth as a person, not just a principle.
The divine act by which God brought the universe into existence. Genesis emphasizes intentionality and goodness; the New Testament affirms Christ as the agent of creation (John 1:3, Colossians 1:16).
God’s revealed standard of righteousness. In the Old Testament, embodied in Mosaic Law; in the New, fulfilled in Christ. The law exposes sin and guides obedience (Romans 7:7).
The work of Christ to reconcile sinners to God, primarily through His substitutionary death. Rooted in the sacrificial system and fulfilled in the cross (Leviticus 16, Romans 3:25).
The giving up of something valuable as an act of worship, often for atonement. Christ’s death is the ultimate and final sacrifice, fulfilling the typology of the Old Testament system (Hebrews 10:10).
Communication with God involving praise, confession, thanksgiving, and requests. Central to both individual piety and corporate worship (Philippians 4:6, Luke 11).
More than the absence of conflict—peace is the fullness of life under God’s blessing. Rooted in covenant and fulfilled in Christ (Isaiah 9:6, John 14:27).
The active rule of God in heaven and on earth. Inaugurated by Christ’s first coming, consummated at His return. It defines the framework of the gospel (Matthew 4:17).
God's assessment and response to human actions. Includes both temporal discipline and eternal destiny. Christ is the appointed judge (Acts 17:31).
God’s absolute moral perfection, and His call for His people to be set apart. Holiness governs worship, ethics, and covenant loyalty (1 Peter 1:16).
God's sovereign choice of individuals or groups for a divine purpose—especially salvation. Emphasized in Romans 9 and Ephesians 1. Intertwined with covenant, grace, and foreknowledge.
The legal act of God declaring a sinner righteous on the basis of faith in Christ. Imputed righteousness (Romans 4), not earned merit.
The act of the Holy Spirit giving spiritual life to the sinner. Also called being “born again” (John 3). The beginning of sanctification and transformation.
Christ’s substitutionary death that satisfies God’s justice and enables reconciliation. Foreshadowed in sacrificial rituals; fulfilled in the cross (Hebrews 9).
The act of buying back from bondage. In salvation, Christ pays the price for sinners with His blood (Ephesians 1:7). In OT, rooted in kinsman-redeemer law.
The legal and spiritual placing of a believer into God's family. Adoption bestows rights of heirs and affirms intimacy with the Father (Romans 8:15–17).
Ongoing spiritual formation by the Holy Spirit. Distinct from justification, it’s a process, not a status—marked by obedience, holiness, and Christlikeness.
The final state of redeemed humanity in full resurrection glory. Includes bodily transformation and sinless perfection (Romans 8:30; 1 Corinthians 15).
The relational result of atonement—God and humanity restored. Also a call for horizontal peace among believers (2 Corinthians 5:18–20).
The literal and visible return of Jesus Christ to earth. Central to Christian hope and judgment, as described in Matthew 24, Acts 1:11, and Revelation 19.
The raising of the body after death. Includes Christ’s resurrection (firstfruits) and the future resurrection of all humans for judgment or glory (1 Corinthians 15).
God’s ultimate judgment of all humanity based on faith, works, and grace. It culminates in eternal destinies (Revelation 20, Matthew 25).
The dwelling place of God and the redeemed. Described as a place of joy, worship, reward, and eternal fellowship with God (Revelation 21).
The final destiny of the unrepentant—separation from God, marked by conscious judgment. Depicted with grave seriousness throughout Scripture (Luke 16, Revelation 20).

lemmas: Not explicitly used outside chilia (G5507) in Revelation 20
definition: A debated period of Christ’s reign before the final judgment. Views include premillennialism, amillennialism, and postmillennialism (Revelation 20:1–6).
A time of great suffering prior to Christ’s return. May refer to both historical Christian persecution and future global distress (Matthew 24:21, Revelation 7:14).
The event where believers are caught up to meet Christ in the air. Central to pre-tribulational eschatology; based on 1 Thessalonians 4:17.
The restored universe following final judgment—free from sin, death, and corruption. Prophesied in Isaiah 65 and Revelation 21.

lemmas: pneuma hagion (G4151 + G40), rûaḥ qōdeš (H7307 + H6944)
definition: The third person of the Trinity—fully God, active in creation, regeneration, sanctification, and empowerment. Sent by Christ to indwell and guide believers (John 14–16, Acts 2).
The immersion of the believer into the body of Christ by the Spirit. Distinguished from water baptism, it often refers to empowerment for ministry (Acts 1:5, 1 Corinthians 12:13).
Supernatural abilities distributed by the Spirit for the edification of the Church. Includes teaching, healing, prophecy, tongues, etc. (1 Corinthians 12–14, Romans 12).
The ethical result of the Spirit’s work in a believer’s life: love, joy, peace, patience, etc. (Galatians 5:22–23). A marker of maturity, not giftedness.
The Spirit’s permanent presence in the believer, beginning at regeneration. Foundation of Christian assurance, power, and transformation (Romans 8:9–11).
Symbol of being set apart and empowered by God. In the NT, all believers are “anointed” by the Spirit (1 John 2:20, 27), not just leaders or prophets.
A willful and final rejection of the Spirit’s testimony about Christ. Marked as unpardonable in the Gospels (Matthew 12:31–32), often interpreted as terminal unbelief.
The Spirit’s role in confirming salvation and belonging. A pledge of the believer’s inheritance until final redemption (Ephesians 1:13–14).
Hindering the Spirit’s activity through disobedience, unbelief, or neglect. A warning given to believers (1 Thessalonians 5:19).
The title for Jesus meaning “Anointed One,” identifying Him as the fulfillment of messianic prophecy. Central to Christian identity and redemptive hope.

lemmas: sarx (G4561), as used in ho logos sarx egeneto (John 1:14)
definition: The eternal Son of God taking on human nature. Fully divine, fully human. A cornerstone doctrine (Philippians 2:6–8, John 1:14).
Jesus' identity as the eternal, divine Son—unique in essence and intimacy with the Father. Affirmed at His baptism, transfiguration, and resurrection.

lemmas: huios tou anthrōpou (G5207 + G444), ben adam (H1121 + H120)
definition: Jesus’ preferred self-title, emphasizing both His humanity and messianic role (Daniel 7, Mark 10:45). Links incarnation with authority and eschatology.
The promised savior-king of the Old Testament. Fulfilled in Jesus, who embodies Israel’s hope and God's redemptive plan.
A theological title for Christ in John 1—“the Word” through whom all things were made. Ties together divine rationality, revelation, and incarnation.
One who reconciles opposing parties. Christ is the sole mediator between God and man (1 Timothy 2:5), fulfilling priestly and legal roles.
A title that identifies Jesus as the fulfillment of Passover imagery and Isaiah 53’s suffering servant. Represents innocence, sacrifice, and victory (John 1:29).
Jesus is the ultimate high priest—offering Himself as the perfect sacrifice and continually interceding for believers (Hebrews 4–10).
The inspired and authoritative written Word of God. Comprises 66 books in the Protestant canon, revealing God’s character, will, and redemptive plan.
The doctrine that God supernaturally guided the human authors of Scripture such that the final writings are His authoritative Word (2 Timothy 3:16).

lemmas: Theological concept; no single lemma—related to aletheia (truth)
definition: Scripture in its original manuscripts is without error in all that it affirms. Rooted in God's character and affirmed by Christ’s use of Scripture.
God making Himself known—both generally through creation and specially through Scripture and Christ (Romans 1; Hebrews 1:1–3).
The Holy Spirit’s work in helping believers understand and apply Scripture. Different from revelation, it operates within the text’s fixed meaning.
The fixed set of inspired books recognized as Scripture. Formed through historical recognition of apostolic authorship and spiritual authority.

lemmas: Theological concept; related to arkeo (G714) – “to be enough”
definition: Scripture contains all we need for salvation, godly living, and spiritual growth. It is not lacking in essential revelation.
The Bible can be understood rightly by ordinary people through ordinary means, especially when read in faith and community.

lemmas: metaphrasis (not in NT), related verb hermēneuō (G2059)
definition:
The process of expressing the inspired text in different languages. Essential for global discipleship and faith transmission (Acts 2:6–11).

⛪ Ecclesiology (Terms 81–90)
The gathered people of God—local and universal. Not a building, but a Spirit-indwelt body united by faith in Christ (Acts 2, Ephesians 4).
A metaphor for the Church as unified yet diverse, with Christ as the head. Emphasizes interdependence and mission (1 Corinthians 12).
A metaphor for the Church’s intimate and covenantal relationship with Christ, awaiting full union at His return (Ephesians 5, Revelation 19).
Deep spiritual sharing in Christ, the Spirit, and the mission. Seen in prayer, generosity, and sacramental life (Acts 2:42, Philippians 1:5).
God-ordained roles of spiritual guidance and accountability in the church—expressed through elders, overseers, and pastors (Titus 1:5–9).
A spiritual leader who feeds, protects, and guides a local church. Reflects Christ as the “Good Shepherd” (Ephesians 4:11, 1 Peter 5).
A mature and spiritually qualified leader tasked with governance, teaching, and care. Always plural in NT governance contexts.
A role focused on practical service, often tied to care for the poor and support of elders. Acts 6 and 1 Timothy 3 outline their function.
A public, symbolic act of union with Christ in death and resurrection. Commanded by Jesus and practiced in the early church (Romans 6, Matthew 28:19).
The unique quality of humanity that reflects God's nature—rationality, morality, creativity, and relationality. Basis for dignity and ethics (Genesis 1:26–27).
The immaterial, personal essence of a human being. Distinct from body but integrated. Capable of relationship with God (Matthew 10:28).
The life-giving, God-aware part of a person—often used interchangeably with soul but emphasizing divine interaction (Ecclesiastes 12:7).
The physical aspect of humanity, created good and destined for resurrection. A temple of the Holy Spirit (1 Corinthians 6:19).
The God-given faculty that discerns ethical truth and convicts of guilt or peace. Can be seared or renewed (Romans 2:15, 1 Timothy 4:2).

lemmas: sarx (G4561), yetzer hara (rabbinic term for evil impulse)
definition: The inherited bent toward sin in all humanity due to Adam’s fall. Total depravity doesn’t mean utter evil, but inability to save oneself (Romans 5:12, Ephesians 2:1–3).

lemmas: No single lemma; systematized from sarx, hamartia (G266)
definition: Every part of human nature is affected by sin. No capacity for spiritual life apart from grace. Part of Reformed theology’s “T” in TULIP.
The guilt and corruption passed from Adam to all humanity. Explains universal sinfulness and need for redemption (Psalm 51:5, Romans 5:12–19).
Created spiritual beings who serve God and minister to believers. Do not possess redemptive roles but often mediate revelation or protection (Hebrews 1:14).
Angels who rebelled with Satan. They oppose God’s purposes, deceive, and oppress. Ultimately subject to Christ’s authority (Mark 5, Revelation 12).
The chief enemy of God and His people. A created being who fell from heaven and now works to deceive and destroy. Defeated by Christ (Revelation 20).
The opportunity or pressure to sin. Not itself sin, but an occasion for obedience or failure. Jesus was tempted but without sin (James 1, Hebrews 4:15).
When a demon inhabits or exerts control over a person. Always portrayed as destructive; deliverance is possible only by Christ’s power (Mark 5, Luke 4).
A being assigned by God for individual protection or ministry. Though not systematized, supported in texts like Matthew 18:10 and Psalm 91.
A leading angelic figure—most notably Michael (Jude 9, Revelation 12). Associated with war, announcement, and final judgment (1 Thessalonians 4:16).
High-ranking angels depicted guarding sacred spaces (Genesis 3:24, Exodus 25). Symbolize God’s holiness and majesty—distinct from sentimental portrayals.
Fiery beings surrounding God's throne, singing “Holy, Holy, Holy” (Isaiah 6). Represent purity, worship, and the terrifying holiness of God.
A mysterious figure in the OT who speaks and acts as God. Often interpreted as a pre-incarnate appearance of Christ (Genesis 16, Exodus 3).
The ongoing conflict between God’s kingdom and demonic forces. Involves prayer, truth, and the “armor of God” (Ephesians 6:10–18).
Willingly aligning with God’s will and commands. Central to discipleship, covenant loyalty, and spiritual maturity (John 14:15; Romans 6:16).
A posture of dependence and reverence toward God, marked by valuing others above oneself (Philippians 2:3; Micah 6:8).
Deep feeling and action for others’ suffering. A defining trait of Jesus’ ministry and a command to His followers (Matthew 9:36; Colossians 3:12).
Active good will expressed through loving deeds. Fruit of the Spirit and evidence of God’s character (Ephesians 4:32).
The capacity to endure hardship or delay without anger or despair. Reflects God’s character and shapes Christian community (James 5:7–11).
Moral consistency rooted in fear of God. Walking blamelessly in public and private life (Proverbs 10:9; Titus 2:7–8).
Freely sharing what one has, reflecting God's grace and provision. Central to early church community life (2 Corinthians 9:6–8).
Living in right relationship with God and others. Seeks the good of the vulnerable and reflects the heart of God (Micah 6:8; Amos 5:24).
Choosing to release others from the debt of wrongdoing. Rooted in God’s forgiveness of us, commanded as a Christian practice (Matthew 6:12–15).
A committed life of following Jesus in word, action, and purpose. Requires self-denial, learning, and perseverance (Luke 9:23; Matthew 28:19).
Staying true to God and His Word. A fruit of the Spirit and mark of godly character (Galatians 5:22; Lamentations 3:23).
The act of declaring the good news of Jesus Christ with the goal of conversion and discipleship (Romans 10:14–15; Acts 1:8).
The honoring of God in spirit and truth through acts of praise, obedience, and reverence (John 4:23–24; Psalm 95).
A divinely instituted rhythm of rest and worship. Rooted in creation, practiced under Mosaic Law, and reinterpreted in Christ (Exodus 20; Hebrews 4).
Managing God’s gifts (time, money, talent) for His purposes. Reflects kingdom values and eternal investment (Matthew 25:14–30; 1 Peter 4:10).
Extending love to outsiders, especially the vulnerable. Required of leaders and patterned by Christ’s inclusivity (Romans 12:13; Hebrews 13:2).
Verbal acknowledgment of sin or truth. Can be vertical (to God) or horizontal (to others), leading to cleansing and restoration (1 John 1:9; James 5:16).
Intimate communication with God in praise, confession, thanksgiving, and request. A hallmark of Christ’s life and Christian maturity (Matthew 6:9–13; Philippians 4:6).
Prayer on behalf of others—mirroring Christ’s ongoing heavenly ministry (Romans 8:34; 1 Timothy 2:1).
Voluntary abstaining from food for spiritual focus. Paired with prayer, repentance, or seeking guidance (Matthew 6:16–18; Ezra 8:21).
A spiritual discipline of listening and reverent attentiveness to God. Found in lament, awe, and waiting (Psalm 62:1; Habakkuk 2:20).
Withdrawing from noise and people to be with God. Practiced by Jesus (Mark 1:35), it fosters clarity, prayer, and spiritual renewal.
A commitment to spiritual transparency and mutual correction in community. Helps prevent drift and fosters growth (Galatians 6:1–2; Hebrews 13:17).
Life together in Christ. Not just proximity, but shared identity, mission, and care (Acts 2:42–47; 1 Corinthians 12).
Spirit-filled words and presence that build up the soul. A vital ministry of the body (Hebrews 3:13; 1 Thessalonians 5:11).
Intentional practices that shape the soul toward godliness (1 Timothy 4:7–8). Includes prayer, study, fasting, and service.
A reality in the fallen world that God uses for sanctification and testimony. Believers share in Christ’s sufferings (1 Peter 4:12–13; Romans 8:18).
The Spirit-empowered ability to remain faithful under pressure. Central to discipleship and crowned in eternity (James 1:12; Hebrews 12:1–2).
Confident anticipation rooted in God’s promises and character. Not wishful thinking but assurance anchored in resurrection and return (Romans 5:2–5).
A deep sense of well-being rooted in relationship with God—not dependent on circumstances. Fruit of the Spirit (Philippians 4:4).
Long obedience in the same direction. Finishing the race with trust and obedience (Romans 5:3–4; Revelation 2:10).
Pressure or affliction, often in persecution. Jesus promises it, yet promises peace within it (John 16:33).
Deep sorrow, often over death or sin. Blessed in the kingdom, for it leads to comfort and nearness to God (Matthew 5:4; Psalm 34:18).
God’s tender reassurance amid sorrow. The Spirit is called the “Comforter.” Believers are called to comfort others (2 Corinthians 1:3–5).
God-ordained challenges to reveal and strengthen faith. Abraham, Job, and Jesus all underwent testing (Genesis 22; James 1:2–3).

lemmas: pronoia (G4307), conceptual; Hebraic roots in pāqad (H6485)
definition: God’s sovereign, wise, and loving guidance of all creation toward His purposes. Includes preservation and concurrence (Genesis 50:20; Romans 8:28).
God's absolute right and power to do all that He wills. His sovereignty governs salvation, nations, and history (Daniel 4:35; Ephesians 1:11).
God possesses infinite power and is able to accomplish His will perfectly. No force can thwart Him (Revelation 19:6; Job 42:2).
God knows all things past, present, and future—fully and effortlessly. He sees hearts and motives (Psalm 139; Hebrews 4:13).
God is present in all places at all times. Not diffused, but fully present everywhere (Jeremiah 23:24; Psalm 139:7–10).
God does not change in essence, character, or promises. He is forever trustworthy and consistent (Malachi 3:6; Hebrews 13:8).
God’s utter moral purity and otherness. The core of His identity—revealed in judgment and mercy (Isaiah 6:3; Revelation 4:8).
God’s self-giving, loyal affection toward His people. Not sentiment but action rooted in covenant (John 3:16; 1 John 4:8).
God’s perfect commitment to what is right. He rewards righteousness and punishes sin (Romans 3:25–26; Deuteronomy 32:4).

lemmas: sarx (G4561 – flesh), as in ho logos sarx egeneto (John 1:14)
definition: The eternal Son of God taking on human nature. Fully divine and fully human, this act inaugurates redemption (Philippians 2:6–8; John 1:14).

lemmas: stauroō (G4717), tsālaq (H6731 – to hang on a tree)
definition: Jesus' sacrificial death to atone for sin. Central to redemption, fulfillment of prophecy, and divine justice (Isaiah 53; Luke 23; Romans 5:8).
The bodily return of Jesus from death—proof of divine power, acceptance of His sacrifice, and guarantee of future resurrection (1 Corinthians 15).
Christ's return to heaven post-resurrection, where He reigns at the Father’s right hand and intercedes for us (Acts 1:9; Hebrews 7:25).

lemmas: kathēmai (G2521), as in “seated at the right hand”
definition: The theological term for Christ seated in glory—signifying completed atonement and ongoing intercession (Hebrews 1:3; Psalm 110:1).
The literal, visible return of Jesus to judge, renew, and reign. A core Christian hope (Titus 2:13; Matthew 24:30).

lemmas: kainos ouranos kai kainē gē (G2537 + G3772 + G2537 + G1093)
definition: God’s final act of cosmic renewal. No more sin, death, or curse—perfect communion restored (Isaiah 65:17; Revelation 21:1–5).
Christ’s triumph over sin, death, and Satan. Believers share in this victory through union with Him (1 Corinthians 15:57; Romans 8:37).
The promised reward for those who remain faithful under trial (James 1:12; Revelation 2:10).
Confident trust in God’s character and promises—especially in Christ’s finished work. Both gift and response (Ephesians 2:8–9; Hebrews 11:1).
Acknowledging the truth of God's revelation, leading to relational trust and obedience (John 3:16; Romans 10:9–10).
Relying on God's character, promises, and provision—especially in uncertainty or adversity (Proverbs 3:5–6; Psalm 56:3).
The outworking of genuine faith through action. Not legalism, but loving surrender to God's revealed will (Romans 1:5; James 2:26).
The pursuit of God’s character in daily life. Called and enabled by the Spirit (1 Peter 1:15–16; Hebrews 12:14).
A lifestyle shaped by awe of God, aligning belief with behavior. A major goal of spiritual formation (1 Timothy 4:7–8; Titus 2:12).
Spiritual and relational oneness rooted in shared faith and love. Grounded in the Trinity, expressed in the Church (John 17; Ephesians 4:3–6).
The tearing apart of Christian unity. Often caused by pride, false teaching, or worldliness (1 Corinthians 1:10–13; Titus 3:10).
Sharing life in Christ—relational, spiritual, and practical. Vital to the Church’s health and witness (Acts 2:42; Philippians 1:5).
God's climactic evaluation of human life—based on faith, works, and Christ’s mediation. Results in eternal destinies (Matthew 25; Revelation 20).
God’s righteous opposition to sin. Not impulsive rage, but holy justice (Romans 1:18; Nahum 1:2–3).
Symbol and agent of divine judgment—and sometimes purification. Final fire tests works and reveals hearts (1 Corinthians 3:13; Hebrews 12:29).
A holy, affectionate reverence that leads to obedience and wisdom. Beginning of knowledge and cornerstone of worship (Proverbs 1:7; Acts 9:31).
Eager pursuit of God’s glory and purposes. Can be holy (like Christ’s) or misdirected (Romans 10:2; John 2:17).
Spirit-empowered confidence to speak and live for Christ. Mark of apostolic witness (Acts 4:31; Ephesians 6:19–20).
Strength channeled by humility and trust in God. Commended by Christ and exalted in the Beatitudes (Matthew 5:5; Galatians 5:23).
The Spirit-enabled ability to distinguish truth from error. Essential for wise living and doctrinal integrity (1 John 4:1; Philippians 1:9–10).
God’s initiative to draw people into relationship and mission. Includes general (salvation) and specific (service) callings (Romans 8:28–30).
God’s entrusting of His people with gospel proclamation and kingdom work. Most clearly expressed in the Great Commission (Matthew 28:18–20).
A specific calling to be sent with Christ’s authority—especially the Twelve and Paul. Broader application in missionary and church-planting roles (Ephesians 4:11).
Speaking on behalf of God by the Spirit. May involve future insight, but primarily aimed at exhortation and revelation (1 Corinthians 14:3; Amos 3:7).
Communicating truth clearly and faithfully. Central to discipleship and doctrinal formation (Matthew 28:20; 2 Timothy 2:2).
Ongoing transformation into Christlikeness through relational learning, obedience, and mission (Luke 14:27; Colossians 1:28).
The dynamic, redemptive reign of God—present in Christ, expanding through the Church, fulfilled in eternity (Mark 1:15; Luke 17:21).
The good news that God reigns through Christ—bringing salvation, justice, and new creation (Matthew 24:14; Luke 4:43).

lemmas: laos theou (G2992 + G2316), ʿam bĕrit (H5971 + H1285)
definition: Those bound to God through His promises—first Israel, then the Church through Christ. Identity rooted in grace (1 Peter 2:9; Genesis 17).
The collective, Spirit-empowered community of believers, with Christ as the Head. Expresses unity, diversity, and mission (1 Corinthians 12).
A metaphor for the Church’s love and loyalty to Christ. Points to future consummation and purity (Revelation 19:7; Ephesians 5:25–27).
All believers are called to offer spiritual sacrifices and intercede. Direct access to God through Christ (1 Peter 2:5; Hebrews 10:19–22).
What believers receive as co-heirs with Christ—eternal life, resurrection, kingdom authority (Romans 8:17; 1 Peter 1:4).
Believers belong to God's eternal kingdom now. Our primary loyalty is to Christ's reign (Philippians 3:20; Hebrews 11:13–16).
The process and goal of being fully formed in Christ. Requires time, teaching, testing, and Spirit-fueled transformation (Hebrews 5:14; Ephesians 4:13).
A life that bears visible outcomes of spiritual health—character, disciples, service (John 15:1–8; Galatians 5:22–23).
A spiritual endowment by the Holy Spirit for calling or ministry. Present in every believer, intensified for specific tasks (1 John 2:20, 27).
Remaining spiritually awake—especially in prayer and preparation for Christ’s return (Matthew 24:42; 1 Peter 5:8).
Dying for one’s faith in Christ. The supreme earthly testimony to eternal allegiance (Acts 7:59–60; Revelation 6:9).
God's generous response to faithful service—not earned salvation, but an eternal gift of grace (Matthew 6:4; 1 Corinthians 3:14).
The cosmic struggle between God's kingdom and Satan. Believers fight with truth, righteousness, and prayer (Ephesians 6:10–18).
One who remains faithful through trial and temptation. Promised eternal reward and presence (Revelation 2–3; Romans 8:37).
The believer’s new nature in Christ—holy, beloved, secure. Lived out in tension with the old self (2 Corinthians 5:17; Colossians 3:12).
Life that begins now through union with Christ and continues forever in God's presence. Not just length but quality (John 17:3; 1 John 5:11).
The fullness of God's beauty revealed—and shared with believers. The goal of redemption and destiny of the saints (Romans 8:30; Revelation 21:23).
A strong affirmation of truth. Used to seal prayers, promises, and doxologies. Christ is Himself called “the Amen” (Revelation 3:14; 2 Corinthians 1:20).
